questions.question: A patient is being evaluated for male infertility. The fertility specialist explains the changes sperm undergo in the epididymis. Which of the following statements correctly describes a change that sperm undergo in the epididymis?

options.A: Ability to bind to zona pellucida develops after ejaculation.
options.B: Cytoplasm and cell volume increases in the epididymis.
options.C: Sperm gain motility and chemotaxis ability.
options.D: Capacitation for fertilization happens in the epididymis.

questions.explanation: ability to sense chemical signals during their passage through the epididymis. Change Description Motility Acquisition Sperm leaving the testes are not fully mobile. They gain progressive motility in the epididymis. Motility is suppressed by inhibitory proteins until ejaculation. Cation Channel Activation Activation of CatSper family cation channels occurs. Alkaline-sensitive Ca2+ channels become active as sperm move to more alkaline cervical mucus. Chemotaxis Development Develop the ability to sense chemical signals from the ovaries, helping guide them toward the ovary. Concentration Become concentrated due to fluid reabsorption. Epididymal Fluid Contribution Epididymis and Sertoli cells secrete nutrient-rich fluid containing hormones, enzymes, and nutrients essential for maturation. Sperm Storage Epididymis serves as the primary storage site. Sperm can maintain fertility for at least a month. Timeframe for Motility Sperm gain the capability for motility after 18 to 24 hours in the epididymis. Full maturation and hypermotility occur in the female genital tract. Acrosome Maturation The acrosome, located at the sperm head and containing enzymes for fertilization, matures while sperm are stored in the epididymis. Decreased Cytoplasm and Cell Volume Sperm lose excess cytoplasm and decrease in overall cell volume as they mature in the epididymis. Zona Pellucida Binding Ability Sperm acquire receptors during epididymal transit that enable them to bind to the zona pellucida, facilitating penetration and fertilization of the egg. Capacitation Post-Epididymis Full fertilization capacity (capacitation) occurs after sperm leave the epididymis. This involves removal of inhibitory factors and changes to the sperm membrane. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 1013-1014 Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 29th Edition, Page 414 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5354101/ https://rep.bioscientifica.com/view/journals/rep/147/2/R27.xml

questions.question: A 15-year-old male is undergoing puberty and starts experiencing physical and hormonal changes associated with this developmental stage. Which hormonal changes and effects are typical during puberty in males?

options.C: Elevated FSH enlarges penis and scrotum.

questions.explanation: stimulates Leydig cells in the testes to produce more testosterone, leading to the development of secondary sexual characteristics. Puberty and Male Reproductive System Changes Increased Testosterone Production Surge in testosterone by Leydig cells in testes. Stimulated by LH from anterior pituitary. (Option B) Primary Sexual Characteristics Growth of penis, scrotum, and testes. (Option C) Secondary Sexual Characteristics Body Hair: Increased growth on pubic area, face, chest, etc. Voice Changes: Deeper voice due to larynx hypertrophy. Skin Changes: Thicker skin, increased sebaceous secretion, acne. Muscle Development: Increased muscle mass (50% greater than females). (Option A) Bone Growth: Enhanced thickness, calcium retention. Metabolic Effects: Increased basal metabolic rate (5-10%), potential increase in red blood cells. Spermatogenesis Sperm production begins and continues throughout life within seminiferous tubules of testes. Role of Hormones in Spermatogenesis FSH: Stimulates Sertoli cells for sperm support. Testosterone: Essential for germ cell growth. Inhibin: Produced by Sertoli cells to regulate FSH and spermatogenesis rate. (Option D) Sperm Maturation and Storage Immature sperm mature in the epididymis, gaining motility (suppressed until ejaculation), stored for at least a month. Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Testicular Axis

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?

options.A: Sertoli cells and Leydig cells together form the blood-testis barrier
options.B: Leydig cells secrete testosterone and androgen-binding protein
options.C: Leydig cells can synthesize cholesterol de novo within them
options.D: Sertoli cells secrete Inhibin B to suppress the release of LH

questions.explanation: meet their cholesterol needs through both de novo synthesis and uptake of extracellular cholesterol from blood for the synthesis of testosterone. Function of Leydig cells: Testosterone secretion is facilitated by Leydig cells. Cholesterol serves as the primary precursor for testosterone synthesis. Leydig cells can synthesize cholesterol internally and also absorb it from the blood via LDL and HDL receptors. Converts DHEA into testosterone. Testosterone moves into the seminiferous tubules (adluminal compartment). Function of Sertoli cells: Only Sertoli cells form the blood-testis barrier (Option A) Nourishment and protection to developing sperm cells. Sertoli cells contain receptors for FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) and androgens, which indirectly support spermatogenesis. Sertoli cells produce androgen binding protein (ABP). (Option B) Sertoli cells express the aromatase enzyme, responsible for converting testosterone to estrogen. They produce extracellular matrix components and anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH/MIS), which induces regression of Müllerian ducts during male fetal development. Sertoli cells secrete Inhibin B , a crucial factor in the testes that negatively regulates FSH secretion (Option D) through feedback mechanisms. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 1012,1018,1022 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2262169/

questions.question: A 14-year-old male presents with delayed puberty. Physical examination reveals small testicular volume and a lack of secondary sexual characteristics. Hormonal tests indicate low testosterone levels but elevated FSH levels. Which of the following functions of Sertoli cells is most likely compromised in this patient? α -reductase

options.A: Secretion of testosterone in response to LH stimulation
options.B: Production of inhibin, leading to increased FSH levels
options.C: Conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone by 5
options.D: Support of spermatogenesis through FSH-mediated stimulation

questions.explanation: plausible explanation for the observed hormonal imbalances and clinical features is a compromised ability of Sertoli cells to respond to FSH stimulation , leading to both impaired spermatogenesis and, consequently, low testosterone levels. The reduced negative feedback from inhibin due to impaired Sertoli cell function further contributes to the elevated FSH levels. Hormones of Spermatogenesis: Follicular stimulating hormone: FSH is essential for the initial development of spermatogonia cells. Main targets of FSH action include: Proliferation of Sertoli cell Proliferation of Spermatogonia up to primary spermatocyte stage Support the process of meiosis. Testosterone: Testosterone is particularly required for the terminal stages of spermatogenesis Main targets of testosterone action include: Spermiogenesis (spermatid to mature sperm) Spermiation (release of sperm) Meiosis (suppression of testosterone leads to block in meiosis) Estrogen: Main targets of Estrogen include: Fluid resorption and concentration of sperm Acrosome biogenesis of sperm Growth hormone: Growth hormone specifically promotes early division of the spermatogonia Option A) Secretion of testosterone in response to LH stimulation is a function of Leydig cell Option B) Production of inhibin leading to increased FSH levels simply does not explain the low testosterone levels seen in this patient Option C) While testosterone does play a role in spermatogenesis, its production is mainly stimulated by LH acting on Leydig cells. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 1013

questions.question: Which of the following components is most accurately matched with its contribution to the total volume of semen?

options.A: Seminal vesicles contribute 20% of the total volume.
options.B: Prostate contributes 60% of the total volume.
options.C: Bulbourethral glands contribute the majority of the semen volume.
options.D: Seminal vesicles contribute 60% of the total volume.

questions.explanation: are responsible for producing approximately 60% of the total volume of semen. The fluid from the seminal vesicles is rich in fructose and other substances that provide energy and aid in the motility of sperm. Sperm Maturation: Spermatogenesis : Begins during adolescence; takes ~74 days. Initial Mobility : Sperm are not fully mobile upon leaving the testes. Maturation : Occurs in the epididymis where sperm gain motility. Motility Mechanism : Involves activation of cation channel proteins (CatSper family) in the sperm tail. Alkaline Sensitivity : CatSpers form an alkaline-sensitive Ca2+ channel, activated as sperm transition from acidic vagina to alkaline cervical mucus. Sperm Capacitation Location : Occurs in the isthmus of the uterine tubes. Purpose : Prepares sperm for the acrosome reaction and increases motility. Contents of Semen Composition : Sperm and fluids from seminal vesicles, prostate, Cowper glands, and potentially urethral glands. Volume : 2.5–3.5 mL per ejaculation after several days of abstinence. Sperm Count : About 100 million sperm per mL. Fluid Source : Seminal vesicles: 60% (Option A) (Option D) Prostate: 20% (Option B) Bulbourethral glands: Remaining portion (Option C) Surface Proteins : Sperm contain proteins like fertilin for egg cell membrane fusion Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 405,412,414

questions.question: At which phase of the menstrual cycle does the primary oocyte complete meiosis I to become a secondary oocyte?
questions.explanation: the completion of meiosis I in the primary oocyte, resulting in the formation of a secondary oocyte and a first polar body. The secondary oocyte then arrests in metaphase II and is released from the follicle. Oogenesis Stages and Hormonal Regulation Stage Events Before Birth Puberty Pituitary gland secretes FSH and LH Follicular Phase (Option A) Ovulation (Option B) Luteal Phase (Option C) Corpus luteum secretes progesterone and some estrogen → If no fertilization, estrogen and progesterone levels decline Fertilization Menstrual phase : The menstrual phase involves the shedding of the uterine lining if fertilization does not occur, and does not involve the completion of meiosis I in the oocyte. (Option D)

questions.question: A 27-year-old woman with a regular 30-day cycle is in the luteal phase. Which of the following statements accurately reflects the hormonal environment and physiological changes during this phase?

options.A: Corpus luteum breaks down, leading to decreased estrogen and progesterone.
options.B: Progesterone levels increase significantly due to the activity of the corpus luteum
options.C: Granulosa and theca interna cells secrete estrogen

questions.explanation: fertilized. (Option A) Corpus luteum breaks down, leading to decreased estrogen and progesterone. Endometrium regresses and sheds. Decreased Estrogen Decreased Progesterone Duration: 4-7 days Blood loss: ~40 mL Serous fluid loss: ~35 mL Follicular Phase (Pre-ovulatory) Initiated by increased follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary. (Option D) Stimulates growth of 6-12 primordial follicles. Granulosa and theca interna cells secrete estrogen. (Option C) Estrogen promotes FSH receptor formation and accelerates follicular growth. One follicle becomes dominant (preovulatory follicle). Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) Estrogen Duration: Variable Follicle growth and maturation occur Luteal Phase (Post-ovulatory) Begins after ovulation with corpus luteum formation. Corpus luteum secretes progesterone and some estrogen. Prepares endometrium for implantation. If no implantation, corpus luteum involutes, decreasing hormone levels and triggering menstruation. Luteinizing Hormone (LH) Progesterone Estrogen Duration: About 12 days Decline in hormones leads to menstruation Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 1028,1030-1032,1037

questions.question: According to the Two-Cell-Two-Gonadotropin Hypothesis, which of the following hormones primarily stimulates granulosa cells in the ovaries to promote the production of estrogen?
questions.explanation: secretion of estradiol by increasing the aromatase activity. Two-Cell-Two-Gonadotropin Hypothesis: Naturally occurring estrogens are 17 β -estradiol, estrone, and estriol. Many LH receptors are present on theca interna cells and LH increases conversion of cholesterol to androstenedione. The theca interna cells supply androstenedione to the granulosa cells. Granulosa cells have many FSH receptors, and FSH (Option B) increases secretion of estradiol by increasing aromatase activity. Thus, both LH and FSH are required for the production of estrogen. LH (Option A) increases progesterone secretion. Progesterone (Option C) and prolactin (Option D) are not directly involved in production of estrogen in granulosa cells. Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 597,598 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/book s/NBK279054/figure/female_the-normal-menstrual-cycle-and-the-control-of-ovulation.F4/ (Image from article)

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with hot flashes, night sweats, and irregular menstrual cycles, suggesting a decrease in estrogen levels. Which of the following is a primary source of estrogen in premenopausal women, and which of the following is an effect of estrogen on the body?

options.A: Adrenal cortex; Maintenance of bone density

questions.explanation: secreted by ovaries in granulosa cells and one of its effects is proliferation of endometrium. Estrogen Progesterone Source Granulosa cells (Option C) , corpus luteum, and placenta Corpus luteum, placenta and ovarian follicles Effects on female genitalia Growth of ovarian follicle Proliferation of endometrium (Option C) Increase the motility of the uterine tubes Increase blood flow in the uterus Increase the amount of uterine muscle and contractility. Antiestrogenic effect on the myometrium, decreasing their excitability Secretory effect on the endometrium Female Secondary Sex Characteristics Enlargement of breasts Female distribution of fat Wide carrying angle Stimulates the development of lobules and alveoli Effects on the Central Nervous System Increase libido Increase the proliferation of dendrites on neurons and the number of synaptic knobs Thermogenic and responsible for the rise in basal body temperature during ovulation Effects on Endocrine Organs Increased secretion of angiotensinogen and thyroid-binding globulin Large doses of progesterone inhibit LH secretion and potentiate the inhibitory effect of estrogens, preventing ovulation. Other effects Retention of salt and water and gain weight just before menstruation Plasma cholesterol-lowering action Vasodilation by increasing the local production of NO. Maintains bone mineral density Stimulates respiration, and the alveolar PCO2 Increases plasma LDL and decreases HDL (Option D) (Option A) The amount of progestin, androgen, and estrogen produced by the adrenal cortex is a minor fraction of the total amount produced in the body. Hence, not the primary source of estrogen. (Option B) Hepatocytes are not involved in estrogen production. Breast enlargement is an effect of estrogen. (Option D) Corpus luteum secretes more progesterone than estrogen. Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 399,400,401 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8836058/

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the feedback regulation mechanism of ovarian function involving estrogen and the hypothalamus-pituitary axis?

options.A: High levels of estrogen stimulate the release of LH and FSH from the pituitary gland .
options.B: Low levels of estrogen inhibit the release of GnRH from the hypothalamus
options.C: High levels of estrogen inhibit the release of GnRH from the hypothalamus
options.D: Low levels of estrogen stimulate the release of progesterone from the ovaries

questions.explanation: Higher estrogen levels inhibit the release of GnRH from the hypothalamus by negative feedback mechanism. Thecal cells are regulated by LH. Granulosa cells are regulated by both LH and FSH. Circulating estrogens inhibit the secretion of GnRH, LH, and FSH. Inhibin from the granulosa cells inhibits FSH secretion. A moderate, constant level of circulating estrogen exerts a negative feedback effect on LH secretion. At 36–48 h before ovulation, the estrogen feedback effect becomes positive, and this initiates the burst of LH secretion (LH surge) that produces ovulation. Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 401,402,403
